job_title: Business Sales Account Executive in Irving, TX
pros:
Branding and a recognizable notch on your resume that can be used as a stepping stone to work for other companies. Being able to work from home, sick pay/time off policies are great.

The benefits and perks are some of the best I've had, but if I'm being honest should be expected from a company of this size. (500,000+ employees)

Formed a lot of great relationships, not only with my FedEx peers, but also my customer base.
cons:
Dated and antiquated technologies, too many redundant mandatory meetings that conflict with valuable selling time. Management is very hands off when you need them for anything, but are quick to spot and point out deficiencies in your work when it's time for evals.

With inside sales we're expected to call on the same leads in our small book of business to somehow regularly uncover new business, we call cycle them over and over again until we do which creates a borderline call center environment. As you begin to saturate your territory with your presence and build relationships over the course of your tenure this becomes increasingly difficult and unrealistic to sustain as there's only so much potential to work with once you start gaining momentum and winning key accounts, especially if your territory alignment doesn't change much.

Being hourly employees there's not enough time in the day to complete the tasks we're graded on and anything done outside of logged calls and e-mails isn't considered actual 'work' in the eyes of leadership which leads to a stressful and overwhelming race to satisfy a call count before you have to call it a day. It's as if the people that provide directive have never worked a day in the job to understand what we actually deal with.

Meanwhile on a daily basis we're expected to plan for the next day, do market research on our customers/industries, submit collaborative cases with other internal channels, find time to conduct business reviews, create pricing presentations, work with pricing analysts to maintain P/L and last but not least one of the main things that plagues this role that leadership turns a blind eye to— picking up the pieces when other OpCo's within FedEx fall short. From customer service issues, operations, billing/revenue, the list goes on. The support tools we're told to leverage for these daily occurrences are nowhere near effective which usually results in more lost time and frustration when all we want to do is support and advocate for our businesses and sell!

When concerns are brought up on metrics and corrupt selling time it's a lot of "back in my day!" talk which is typical sales deflection. Most of these comments made by Directors/VP's who sold 15-20 years ago during simpler times, back when there was far less competition like Amazon and other large players to contend with. Customers also weren't as educated and equipped with innovation at their fingertips like now.

Your experience will vary and is heavily dictated by which state your territory is in, what type of industry/market you serve and so many other variables outside of your control.

The growth path is also too linear, the only way to move up is to actually MOVE, as in to another state to show FedEx how much you're willing to sacrifice for the company. All for a marginal salary increase and basically keeping the same title. Kiss it goodbye if you're trying to advance in your domicile location because people rarely resign from these positions if you're in a major market so you are forced to make the move if you want to advance. If you cannot do that you've essentially bottlenecked in this role.

This job has evolved to become a revolving door with the recent changes, you better move quick or it'll eventually hit you on your way out. All this is coming from a former employee that has met and exceeded plan during my entire tenure falling in the top 5-10 of my region with numbers and compensation to back it.

Some of the leadership wants to see change however, hard to do with culture. Most people are afraid of making mistakes and this leads to disempowerment. Top level management need to lead the change in culture. They also need to recognize the strengths and weaknesses of the company so that they can be addressed.

pros: You get an okay paycheck for not being experienced, but after 3 or 4 months it becomes clear you're being underpaid.
cons:
No protection from contractors lowering pay.
Fedex constantly undermines the delivery drivers and are extremely petty.
No quality job training, I have seen multiple new drivers start driving without taking their driving test. 
Lot's of fraternization and favoritism among contractors and Fedex Managers.
No room for advancement, as in you're a driver and that is all they will ever let you be.
Absolutely no concern for your safety or well being, You're just a warm body to them.
The contractor system is setup to give Fedex a way to never take responsibility and always put everything on drivers.
No accountability for their own employees, they are not required to take drug tests, don't get reprimanded for throwing packages, etc..
No health insurance, no paid time off or vacation days, 
A driver once stepped off her truck and broke her ankle while at the terminal and did not receive any kind of workmans comp .
We're constantly advised to lie about log in and drive times, which is a DOT violation.
In summary, they don't care about you and this should only be a temporary job so you have a chance at getting an ok paycheck until you find a better job.

pros: There are really good people working at FedEx and the organisation supports its employees well. Whilst HR leaves a lot to be desired, the management teams generally care about their teams and work hard to support them. If you're in a place where you want stability and predictability, FedEx could be a great company for you. It offers great benefits and attractive salaries to its staff as well as nice opportunities for personal development.
cons: FedEx is an in-effective company that hasn't moved with the times. It's top-down and top-heavy structure makes it incredibly slow moving and leadership is, at best, indecisive. Time is wasted sat in meetings, reviewing powerpoint slides, debating approaches and ownership rather than getting stuff done. If you get energy from making a difference and having an impact, this probably isn't the place for you.

review_title: Great for a time, but misses the mark for the long run.
job_title: Business Sales Account Executive in Irving, TX
pros:
Branding and a recognizable notch on your resume that can be used as a stepping stone to work for other companies. Being able to work from home, sick pay/time off policies are great.

The benefits and perks are some of the best I've had, but if I'm being honest should be expected from a company of this size. (500,000+ employees)

Formed a lot of great relationships, not only with my FedEx peers, but also my customer base.
cons:
Dated and antiquated technologies, too many redundant mandatory meetings that conflict with valuable selling time. Management is very hands off when you need them for anything, but are quick to spot and point out deficiencies in your work when it's time for evals.

With inside sales we're expected to call on the same leads in our small book of business to somehow regularly uncover new business, we call cycle them over and over again until we do which creates a borderline call center environment. As you begin to saturate your territory with your presence and build relationships over the course of your tenure this becomes increasingly difficult and unrealistic to sustain as there's only so much potential to work with once you start gaining momentum and winning key accounts, especially if your territory alignment doesn't change much.

Being hourly employees there's not enough time in the day to complete the tasks we're graded on and anything done outside of logged calls and e-mails isn't considered actual 'work' in the eyes of leadership which leads to a stressful and overwhelming race to satisfy a call count before you have to call it a day. It's as if the people that provide directive have never worked a day in the job to understand what we actually deal with.

Meanwhile on a daily basis we're expected to plan for the next day, do market research on our customers/industries, submit collaborative cases with other internal channels, find time to conduct business reviews, create pricing presentations, work with pricing analysts to maintain P/L and last but not least one of the main things that plagues this role that leadership turns a blind eye to— picking up the pieces when other OpCo's within FedEx fall short. From customer service issues, operations, billing/revenue, the list goes on. The support tools we're told to leverage for these daily occurrences are nowhere near effective which usually results in more lost time and frustration when all we want to do is support and advocate for our businesses and sell!

When concerns are brought up on metrics and corrupt selling time it's a lot of "back in my day!" talk which is typical sales deflection. Most of these comments made by Directors/VP's who sold 15-20 years ago during simpler times, back when there was far less competition like Amazon and other large players to contend with. Customers also weren't as educated and equipped with innovation at their fingertips like now.

Your experience will vary and is heavily dictated by which state your territory is in, what type of industry/market you serve and so many other variables outside of your control.

The growth path is also too linear, the only way to move up is to actually MOVE, as in to another state to show FedEx how much you're willing to sacrifice for the company. All for a marginal salary increase and basically keeping the same title. Kiss it goodbye if you're trying to advance in your domicile location because people rarely resign from these positions if you're in a major market so you are forced to make the move if you want to advance. If you cannot do that you've essentially bottlenecked in this role.

This job has evolved to become a revolving door with the recent changes, you better move quick or it'll eventually hit you on your way out. All this is coming from a former employee that has met and exceeded plan during my entire tenure falling in the top 5-10 of my region with numbers and compensation to back it.

pros: You get an okay paycheck for not being experienced, but after 3 or 4 months it becomes clear you're being underpaid.
cons:
No protection from contractors lowering pay.
Fedex constantly undermines the delivery drivers and are extremely petty.
No quality job training, I have seen multiple new drivers start driving without taking their driving test. 
Lot's of fraternization and favoritism among contractors and Fedex Managers.
No room for advancement, as in you're a driver and that is all they will ever let you be.
Absolutely no concern for your safety or well being, You're just a warm body to them.
The contractor system is setup to give Fedex a way to never take responsibility and always put everything on drivers.
No accountability for their own employees, they are not required to take drug tests, don't get reprimanded for throwing packages, etc..
No health insurance, no paid time off or vacation days, 
A driver once stepped off her truck and broke her ankle while at the terminal and did not receive any kind of workmans comp .
We're constantly advised to lie about log in and drive times, which is a DOT violation.
In summary, they don't care about you and this should only be a temporary job so you have a chance at getting an ok paycheck until you find a better job.

pros: Work honestly isn’t too hard, pay and benefits are decent
cons: Pay is only decent if you manage to work enough hours, I’m currently working 7 days a week to make more than $500. Kinda wack when I make 14.50 and have made way more weekly making less per hour. It’s just volume based hours and it’s not consistent

pros: There are really good people working at FedEx and the organisation supports its employees well. Whilst HR leaves a lot to be desired, the management teams generally care about their teams and work hard to support them. If you're in a place where you want stability and predictability, FedEx could be a great company for you. It offers great benefits and attractive salaries to its staff as well as nice opportunities for personal development.
cons: FedEx is an in-effective company that hasn't moved with the times. It's top-down and top-heavy structure makes it incredibly slow moving and leadership is, at best, indecisive. Time is wasted sat in meetings, reviewing powerpoint slides, debating approaches and ownership rather than getting stuff done. If you get energy from making a difference and having an impact, this probably isn't the place for you.

Opportunities to Learn and Advance
Another benefit of switching jobs is that it can open doors to learn and advance in a career. Changing jobs also lets workers escape dead-end jobs and continue to learn and grow.
